title.narrative: Addressing acute food insecurity in Pibor

description.narrative: The changing dynamics of armed conflict and violence and pockets of violence in South Sudan between state and none state actors continue to challenge well-being of people and delivery of services to the community by government and humanitarian organizations. While there is hope for South Sudan’s Nationals to the long-awaited implementation of the Revitalized Peace Process promised to offer new opportunities in 2019, its implementation still hangs in balance. Moreover, the cumulative effects of years of conflict, violence and destroyed livelihoods have left more than 8.3 million people in dire need of some form of humanitarian assistance and protection (UN 2021). Compared to the current levels of violent conflict in South Sudan, Greater Jonglei state is significantly affected by both political and tribal conflicts. Apart from the national level conflicts, there are several inter- and intra-state and community level conflicts that require the attention of all development actors in South Sudan. Traditional practices have had negative impacts on the desired peaceful co-existence in the communities. In addition to these, causes of conflicts such as military recruitment arms proliferation and social fragmentation, there are natural calamities like floods and long dry spells that affect the agricultural cycles. Jonglei and Greater Administrative Area of Pibor is one of the states hardest hit by the crises, with currently 47% of the population in need of severity phase extreme or catastrophic (HNO 2021 people in need by severity phase, gender, age and disability). Torrential rains in 2020 led to severe flooding in large areas of South Sudan, and OCHA estimates that more than 900,000 people have been affected (Update #3, 5 November 2020). In Pibor County, Jonglei, the situation is the worst, with an unprecedented 319,000 persons affected (ICWG, 5 November 2020). The population, who are primarily dependent on small-scale farming, has seen their livelihoods been flushed away: granary stores are damaged, fields are destroyed and livestock have drowned in large numbers. Alarmingly, 53% of the flood-affected counties were already in IPC 3 (critical) or IPC 4 (emergency) before the floods hit these areas (IPC Acute Food Insecurity & Malnutrition Assessment distributed through WFP, August 2020). In Pibor, the flooding has affected people who were already very food insecure and using negative coping strategies to deal with the situation. In addition, intercommunal violence and cattle-raiding between the Lou Nuer and Murle communities has led to loss of lives and disrupted food assistance delivery to flood-affected populations in Gumuruk and Lekwangole payams and Pibor Town.
To contribute to improved access to food and WASH of flood and conflict affected people in South Sudan.
Total beneficiaries: 14,000 individuals in total (based on number of persons per household in Pibor; 7/HH) Women: 3,920 Children: 6,720 Men: 1,680 Elderly: 1,540 Disabled: 140

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Sustainable Livelihoods Corporate Indicators
Number of people with improved food security

description.narrative: Number of households with an improved score on the household food insecurity access scale (HFIAS) compared to the baseline score. This score is a household score and needs to be translated to the number of individual household members (based on average household size).

title.narrative: Water Supply
WSH-I4: Number of people having access to sufficient and safe water for domestic use

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Safe: 1) low risk of faecal contamination, 2) No faecal coliforms detectable in any 100-ml sample, 3) For piped water supplies, or for all water supplies at times of risk or presence of diarrhoea epidemic, water is treated with a disinfectant to achieve free chlorine residual at the tap of 0.5 mg per litre and turbidity is below 5 NTU, 4) If for a short period, water which is contaminated chemically or radiologically is used, no (significant probability of) negative health effect is (likely to be) detected. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

title.narrative: Availability of, access to and consumption of food
FSC-I2: Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs (non-cash)

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, cash) and combination thereof with objective to ensure immediate access to the necessary food commodities. This may include supplementary foods provided alongside general distribution for vulnerable people.

title.narrative: Short-term livelihood support
FSC-I1: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihoods assets

description.narrative: Resources that enable people to protect and rebuild their livelihood assets include seeds, livestock, tools, business grant, etc. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, restricted cash) and combination thereof to support, protect and enable the restoration/protection/access of/to livelihood assets.

title.narrative: Non-food items
SHL-I4: Number of people provided with non-food items (other than hygiene/dignity kits)

description.narrative: Distribution of Non-Food Items. All household materials excluding those that fall under hygiene/dignity kits or direct shelter items. Also excludes unrestricted cash, which is to be put under indicator CSH-I1 or CSH-I2. However, if cash is provided for the purpose of buying household items, it should be put under this indicator (i.e. restricted cash).

title.narrative: Accountability
% of feedback and valid complaints received that are responded to/resolved

description.narrative: Percent of feedback and valid complaints received at project or country/field office level, via Cordaid, a partner or consortium member that are respond to and/or resolved (in accordance with Cordaid FCM minimum standards). This excludes invalid and sensitive complaints.

Number of people with improved food security

description.narrative: Number of households with an improved score on the household food insecurity access scale (HFIAS) compared to the baseline score. This score is a household score and needs to be translated to the number of individual household members (based on average household size).

description.narrative: Access: maximum distance to water point 500m, queuing time less than 15min, filling time maximum 3 min/20 litres or as locally agreed. Water access should be during the whole period of implementation unless action is mostly related to building the local water delivery capacity. Sufficient: covering basic needs, i.e. 7.5-15 l/p/d or as locally agreed. Domestic use: drinking, cooking and personal hygiene (incl. laundry)

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action. description.narrative: Resources that enable people to protect and rebuild their livelihood assets include seeds, livestock, tools, business grant, etc. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, restricted cash) and combination thereof to support, protect and enable the restoration/protection/access of/to livelihood assets.

title.narrative: The humanitarian response was Appropriate

description.narrative: Appropriateness is assessed according to the SPHERE standards. A response is considered to be appropriateness based on needs assessment, taking account of rights, needs, culture, age, gender, disabilities and context, and equity (non-discrimination and equal access.

title.narrative: SHL-I4: Number of people provided with non-food items (other than hygiene/dignity kits)

description.narrative: Distribution of Non-Food Items. All household materials excluding those that fall under hygiene/dignity kits or direct shelter items. Also excludes unrestricted cash, which is to be put under indicator CSH-I1 or CSH-I2. However, if cash is provided for the purpose of buying household items, it should be put under this indicator (i.e. restricted cash).

title.narrative: Number of beneficiaries reached (SL)

description.narrative: Number of people who benefitted directly or indirectly with life-saving humanitarian assistance and/or resilient recovery services and/or disaster preparedness from activities in a humanitarian response implemented by Cordaid and implementing partners

title.narrative: % of people satisfied with humanitarian assistance received

description.narrative: Percent of people who are satisfied with the humanitarian response they received from Cordaid and implementing partners. Satisfaction to be assessed according to the opinion of the people receiving the assistance.

title.narrative: The Humanitarian Response was Timely

description.narrative:
SPHERE: Communities and people affected by crisis, including the most vulnerable groups, consider that the timing of the assistance and protection they receive is adequate. DRA: timely depends on the nature of the acute crisis (slow versus sudden onset). If it is an acute sudden onset crisis a response is considered timely if we decide to respond within 48 hours and if we initiate the response within 72 hours. If it is a slow onset crisis, it is timely if we initiate the response in 3 weeks after we decide that the crisis meets the criteria of an acute crisis.
The applicable definition depends on the type of crisis (protracted versus acute). The SPHERE definition should be used in more protracted crisis where there is (more) time to conduct assessments and measure satisfaction of the response in the eyes of people affected. The DRA definition should be used for acute crises, where it is more important to initiate the response as soon as possible and look at our own processes.

title.narrative: Climate Resilience
The project integrates climate risks in programming

description.narrative: The integration of climate risks in programming includes an undertaking of concrete actions to reduce and/or mitigate risks related to climate change impact and disaster risks ( for example droughts, erosion, salinization, flooding, etc.) The projects we refer to could be on the themes of health education, justice, security, disaster management, finance and livelihoods.
